thread.title: Northern line extension: Machines lowered into place to begin work on £1.2bn Tube extension
thread.title_full: Northern line extension: Machines lowered into place to begin work on £1.2bn Tube extension

author: dick Murray
title: Northern line extension: Machines lowered into place to begin work on £1.2bn Tube extension
text:
14   Down to earth: the machines, named Helen and Amy, are lowered into place 
In the shadow of the old Battersea Power station a crane lowers the first of two huge drilling machines – named Helen and Amy - to begin tunnelling on what will be the £1.2 billion Northern line extension. 
The tunnels will extend the Charing Cross branch of the Northern line from Kennington to Battersea Power station via Nine Elms - bringing the Tube network to a huge area of south London currently devoid of Underground services. 
Helen and Amy will work for six months on the twin tunnels, 20 metres below ground, targeted for completion in 2020. It is the first major Tube line extension since the Jubilee line in the late 1990s. 
They were named, thanks to a vote by local schoolchildren, in honour of astronaut Helen Sharman and aviation pioneer Amy Johnson. Lowered into place: One of the two giant machines 
When fully assembled the two 650-tonne machines, each the length of a football pitch, will begin their onward journey towards Kennington in March. 
More than 300,000 tonnes of earth will have to be excavated and transferred onto Thames barges where it will be taken down river to East Tilbury for use on farmland. 
Transport for London said the two station extension will create up to 25,000 jobs and 20,000 new homes. Extension: The Northern line will run to Battersea Power Station and Nine Elms from 2020 (Transport for London) 
Journey times from Nine Elms or Battersea to the West End and City could take less than 15 minutes making a huge economic impact on the designated regeneration area of the South Bank. 
It will also help relieve major congestion at Vauxhall Station on the Victoria line. 
Of the cost, £1 billion in funding will be provided by the private sector. More about:
